Introduction

Biliary atresia (BA) is an obliterative disease of the extrahepatic bile ducts that presents with signs and symptoms of biliary obstruction in the first 2 months of life.  Without surgical intervention, BA can progress to cirrhosis, liver failure, and death.

Pathophysiology



The pathogenesis of BA likely involves complex interactions between various factors (eg, environmental triggers, genetic susceptibility).



An initial insult (eg, viral infection, environmental toxin) to the extrahepatic bile ducts (eg, common hepatic duct, common bile duct) triggers an immune-mediated inflammatory response that results in fibrosis of the extrahepatic biliary tree, including the gallbladder (

figure 1
).



Over time, fibrotic obliteration (atresia) of the extrahepatic bile ducts obstructs bile flow into the intestines (cholestasis) (

figure 2
).  As a result, the following occurs:



  • Impaired bilirubin excretion:  Bilirubin, a product of heme metabolism, is normally conjugated in the liver and then transported through the bile ducts and gallbladder to the intestines for excretion in stool.

    • Newborns with BA have normal bilirubin production and conjugation, but decreased bilirubin excretion due to extrahepatic bile duct obstruction.
    • Conjugated (direct) bilirubin accumulates in the plasma, resulting in jaundice and dark urine (due to renal excretion of excess bilirubin).  Conversely, because bilirubin cannot enter the intestines, stools appear pale or acholic due to absent biliary pigment.
  • Intrahepatic bile duct proliferation:  Cholestasis triggers proliferation of bile ductâ€“like cells from progenitor biliary epithelial cells.
  • Bile acid retention:  Retained bile acids contribute to hepatocellular injury that can progress to fibrosis and cirrhosis.


The fibrotic liver parenchyma increases resistance to blood flow through the portal vein, eventually leading to portal hypertension.

Risk factors



Several factors may contribute to the pathogenesis of BA and include viral infections, environmental toxins, and genetic predisposition.

Clinical presentation



Patients with BA are usually asymptomatic at birth but experience the following at age 2-8 weeks:



  • Scleral icterus and jaundice:  excess conjugated bilirubin
  • Dark urine:  excess renal bilirubin excretion
  • Acholic stools:  impaired intestinal bilirubin excretion


As the disease progresses, patients can develop hepatomegaly and splenomegaly (due to portal hypertension).

Diagnosis



Patients with suspected BA undergo laboratory testing for jaundice.  In these patients, laboratory values are consistent with a cholestatic pattern as follows (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
):



  • Elevated total and direct bilirubin is due to cholestasis.
  • Elevated gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) and alkaline phosphatase are caused by bile duct destruction.
  • Normal/elevated aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase levels occur early in the disease process.  These levels may be minimally elevated or even normal because there is limited hepatocellular injury.  As cholestasis progresses, aminotransferase levels may rise further, likely reflecting bile-induced hepatocellular injury.
  • Normal reticulocyte count confirms the absence of hemolysis as a cause for hyperbilirubinemia.


In patients with BA, the GGT is disproportionately elevated compared to bilirubin and aminotransferase levels, consistent with the initial damage at the extrahepatic biliary tract.



If laboratory results are suggestive of BA, further diagnostic evaluation is indicated, including:



  • Right upper quadrant ultrasonography:  Characteristic findings include an absent or abnormal gallbladder, absent common bile duct, and triangular cord sign (fibrous remnants seen above the porta hepatis).  Although right upper quadrant ultrasonography is not diagnostic, gallbladder involvement is highly suggestive of BA.
  • Liver biopsy:  Characteristic findings include intrahepatic bile duct proliferation, portal tract edema with neutrophilic infiltrate, and bile duct plugs with portal fibrosis.


If imaging and biopsy results support the diagnosis of BA, definitive diagnosis is with intraoperative cholangiography, which demonstrates biliary obstruction.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for BA includes any condition that can cause neonatal jaundice.  Jaundice can occur if any step in bilirubin metabolism  is dysregulated, as seen in the following conditions (

figure 3
):



  • Excess hemolysis (eg, ABO incompatibility, hereditary spherocytosis):  Excess hemolysis leads to unconjugated (not conjugated) hyperbilirubinemia.  Patients develop anemia with an elevated reticulocyte count.
  • Inherited disorders of bilirubin conjugation (eg, Gilbert syndrome, Criggler Najjar):  In these conditions, reduced uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase activity leads to impaired bilirubin conjugation (
    figure 4
    ).  Patients have varying degrees of jaundice and indirect (rather than direct) hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Galactosemia (galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency):  This condition is characterized by defective metabolism of galactose, a monosaccharide that is isomerized to glucose.  Patients develop liver dysfunction, and both direct and indirect bilirubin levels can be elevated.  Patients experience vomiting, diarrhea, and lethargy during the first few days (not weeks) of life due to the inability to digest breast milk or formula.
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:  This is a genetic disorder in which abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin accumulates in the liver.  Patients can have neonatal cholestasis and elevated transaminase levels.  Liver biopsy reveals diastase-resistant globules in hepatocytes that are positive for periodic acid-Schiff (
    image 1
    ).
  • Alagille syndrome:  This autosomal dominant disorder affects multiple organ systems (eg, cardiac, vertebral, renal), including the liver.  Patients can have cholestasis and elevated GGT, similar to BA.  However, liver biopsy reveals a paucity of intrahepatic bile ducts (in contrast to intrahepatic bile duct proliferation in BA).
  • Jaundice related to neonatal feeding:  This breastfeeding failure jaundice is seen in the first few days of life and occurs due to inadequate breast milk intake, resulting in delayed transit and elimination of bilirubin.  Breast milk jaundice, which peaks at age 2 weeks, is caused by increased beta-glucuronidase in breast milk, which unconjugates intestinal bilirubin.  Both conditions result in increased enterohepatic circulation and indirect hyperbilirubinemia.

Management



The treatment of BA is surgical management with a hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure), in which the small intestine is directly attached to the liver to reestablish bile flow to the small intestine (

figure 5
).  Urgent surgical intervention is required to prevent cirrhosis, which can lead to liver failure and death within 2 years.



Following hepatoportoenterostomy, patients require ongoing supportive care (eg, nutritional support, fat-soluble vitamin supplementation) and surveillance for potential complications (eg, cholangitis, portal hypertension).

Prognosis



The long-term prognosis of BA is variable and depends on the following factors:



  • Early surgical intervention:  Survival outcomes improve if hepatoportoenterostomy is performed before age 2 months.  However, although hepatoportoenterostomy reestablishes bile flow, the disease is progressive, and most patients (~80%) eventually require liver transplantation.
  • Delayed liver transplant:  Survival outcomes improve if liver transplantation is performed after age 2.


With optimal management, many patients with BA live into adulthood.  However, patients are at increased risk for morbidity, including cholangitis, neurodevelopmental delay, and poor growth.

Summary



Biliary atresia (BA) (
